text: Yeah man. Ever since I got into photography Every time you see a person using a cellphone as a main camera you feelâ€¦ idk, like replaced? A dedicated camera will always be better in nearly every way. But whatâ€™s happening is that cellphones do one crucial part automatically, which is editing. This really only works for people who are too lazy to edit anything or put any dedicated time into a photo or are one of those social media addicts who â€œneedâ€ to post quiet often and consistently. This reduces interest and production in entry level cameras these days. This leads to everyone thinking that photography is super easy and hence people value it less. On a Dedicated camera you need to worry about so many things like shutter speed, aperture, iso, lighting, composition, etc. On a phone itâ€™s just. Snap! Done. Already edited and ready as a .jpeg to post/use. I see this good for maybe like taking a picture for a price tag or password or something as a quick thing (like I get it, who the heck is gonna use an expensive camera for showing a price tag to your wife for example.) but like this whole smartphone auto edit photo stuff is just ruining photography in my opinion.

text:
The things is, all the things a smartphone camera does has always been possible. The only difference now is what used to be hours if not days of work, is done with a single click.

You could take your camera, digital or analog, shoot at different shutterspeeds, swap lenses and in time you have plenty of data gathered. So you go home and start adding all that together and in the end you have one amazing photo. 

Or, you get the latest and greatest smartphone, hit that shutter button and all that data is gather in a matter of seconds. And with plenty of computing power the photo is equally quickly put together.

What I'm actually more hoping for is the day when entry level DSLRs comes with features such as pixel binning to improve on their night photography. Smartphones are almost too good, so it's time for the DSLRs to catch up!

text:
This is simple to me, being someone who wants an incredible amount of control over pictures and having 3 different versions of gcam ports installed at all times:

Make 2 modes.

Regular and faithful/neutral.

The regular mode would be your average modern camera app, with all of its trickery and smart AI whatevers turned on so that the picture matches the manufacturer's vision and average Joe's needs.

The faithful mode would either spit out the most true to life picture or would give you the controls so that you can do it yourself, including switches for stuff most people don't even know are happening, far more advanced than a pro mode, like turning edge sharpening on or off etc.

It's not that hard. Apps like OpenCamera and, well, Gcam already allow for this control, they're just not specialized and 100% stable because it's not the manufacturer of the specific device that's developing them, which would solve a lot of the issues and limitations even they have. Give us both worlds and allow us to switch between them. It's not as simple as this example, but imagine if this talk was over light and dark mode in a world where you could only have 1.

That being said, this is not happening (at least not right now) and I'm not ok with how smartphone cameras are approached currently.

text: Hey Marques, thanks for bringing up this topic of should cameras morph reality? I have been thinking about this for a while. Since I was little I really wanted to see the northern lights - the bright green ribbons of light dancing in the sky. But this idea of northern lights was completely shattered when I actually saw it in reality over a year ago. They were not so green and not so bright. And I felt both disappointed and somewhat cheated. At that moment, I saw other people taking photos of the northern lights in front of us and realized what a difference long exposure can make - to the extent that it was a glorified version of the northern lights which ruined my actual experience of it.

text:
I think smartphones are not going to advance much in terms of sensor size (for portability reasons) which is the real factor in higher photo quality so they compensate heavily by taking the RAW format and adding contrast, saturation, sharpness (most times way too much sharpness), and creating a "HDR" effect in a matter of seconds which is impressive but now they have to keep moving forward in terms of what "features" they add with every new phone released every year so they start adding all these "computational" photography AI features which would probably appeal to the average user who is just looking to snap a quick photo but ultimately give less control/flexibility for those looking to add their own flair to their photos.
Highly compressed JPEG photos which have already been processed by the phone itself are not very "editable".

As a both DSLR and a Sony mirrorless camera owner/photographer, I personally prefer more natural photos on my phone when I don't have my camera with me to shoot.
But then again, there is always the "Pro" mode on Android smartphones that give more control over a photo plus RAW format (the only format I use to take photos as well as most professional photographers).

But this obsession with a "perfect" photo is becoming worse by smartphones adding features to change one's facial features and is not psychologically healthy for future generations in the long run, feeding the insecurities of many people especially young ones. People no longer feel good enough with their real self.
Feeding self image issues... but this has been going on with social media for a long time and probably isn't anything to do with smartphones "advancing" in these areas but its certainly making it easier for the people who don't know how to use editing apps on their phones.

text:
I should first say that I'm not really the average consumer, as probably most of your viewers neither, and more a tech enthusiast with more requirements. I want the smartphone camera to closely replicate what I'm seeing (well, zoom function aside). I don't want the camera to fiddle around so much, but some processing for the small sensor surely is required to get the image as intended. Some clever function like the one to keep the face of a moving person sharp, by shooting another low-shutter image and merging those, is great and I don't see any problem with it - it tries to minimize the technical limitations to give you the intended output. But I don't want a stock image of the moon mapped to my photo of it, that just feels wrong and while maybe the output I strive to achieve, it's fake and just not what I'm actually shooting. Might as well take a reasonable image from Google and claim it's mine.
I also don't like the over-processing of some phones, or rather, some situations by phones. Some HDR photos look lifeless and flat because there is barely any dynamic anymore, or saturation being overblown and photos of vegetation looking artificial. And lastly, over-sharpening causing halos and/or aliasing - that seems to be a general problem with phones nowadays, removing a lot of detail by noise reduction and then slapping (too much) sharpening on top of that. It's one of the few complaints I have regarding the camera of my Pixel 4a; and yes, I use that phone that does a lot of processing, but at the same time it keeps things fairly natural and I'm satisfied most of the time or even impressed with the photos it can take.
Actually, the sharpening seems to be a general problem nowadays, or at least my personal issue disliking it, following me from smartphone cameras to movies (on physical media at least) and even (video) games - make it blurry and then sharpen it, no one will notice that all the fine detail is gone apparently.. :/

text: The moon doesn't always look the same. It undergoes something called libration which means it wobbles slightly from side to side, so different shots of the moon taken at different times should look slightly different. And that's how they probably spotted all the moon pictures were faked. There is a gif on the wikipedia page which demonstrates this.

text: This also makes me worried DSLR/Mirrorless cameras will begin adopting these computational processes from smartphones, which is fine only as long as the option remains to turn them off.
author: @Yougimpytube

text:
Â @YougimpytubeÂ  It always will have an option to turn it off on a mirrorless/dslr camera. 2 reasons for that 1) most professionals use DSLR/mirrorless cameras and they shoot photos in RAW and 2) many of these "edits" are done to JPEG formats... so the option to turn these off will be there otherwise everybody will have to shoot in RAW format which then hurts the companies sales if the person buying the camera is a beginner/intermediate photographer or anybody that prefers to shoot only in JPEG format.
(although I don't understand why someone would ever shoot in compressed JPEG over RAW other than file size reasons but some people really do prefer to edit JPEGS for some odd reason).

Also another point, mirrorless cameras and DSLRs will not be able to do these things (not for the near future atleast) since this level of computational photography requires very powerful processing chips and proper camera companies are most likely not going to invest in that.

Just my thoughts on this. I always shoot RAW on my Sony A7iii anyways so this fake "ready to post" edited thing doesn't bother me.

text:
I don't like the direction technology is going more and more, where everything seems to be automated and predicted and people need to do and think less and less for almost everything in life. I mean, it is great to have video calls from anywhere in the world, play video games with friends, have powerful computers to create multimedia content etc, but for the past few years, technology goes more and more in a direction that makes people more and more worthless... If we continue to follow that path, I can see a future where everyone is wearing a VR headset, laying in their bed and doing everything from there. And when I'm saying everything, I don't mean everything productive because all the productive things will be replaced by AI, so people are only going to do things like consuming contend pathetically...
At that point, I think we will miss the old days where everything was more difficult to do and required more effort and time, but we had goals and as humans and as we accomplishing them we were getting way more satisfaction with our accomplished result than having almost everything ready to consume in front of us with zero effort.

text: Photographs are meant to capture a moment, an experience. Even an "untimely" blinking of an eye is what makes that moment unique in our lives. Altering that to fit what we think is perfect or what is socially acceptable is a dangerously slippery slope. We all tried to edit some photo we captured once in our lives but what really gives pause for thought is do we edit the photos because we think it looks better or do we edit the photos because we think other people will think it looks better? We sometimes forget that we usually see ourselves as a still photograph but everyone around us see a living moving face with all its quirks and blemishes. Makes me think that we don't even know ourselves sometimes. Learn to accept yourself a little more everyday.

text:
I can verify that smart phone cameras are not accurate. They're getting much better with that, though. But you will notice minor differences between yourself irl vs a smart phone camera.
You shouldn't let these minor differences change the way you see yourself; it's an illusion.

Unless you deliberately look for the angles that look nothing like you do IRL.
For those of you reading this, you have an addiction that can only be fulfilled by falsely believing you look like your best angles. The truth is, you're a catfish.

But for the rest of us who don't struggle with major insecurities, it shouldn't be too hard to disregard a bad photo.

text:
What is reality?  Your eyes do not see objectively as interpreted by your brain, nor are your memories objective.  While at once it seems creepy, on the other hand, our brain does this to us all the time  whether it is a painting that follows our eyes, colors that don't actually exist, or the rose colored glasses through which we view our youth.

After all, eye witness testimony is the worst kind of evidence of all.

text:
For me what I want from a camera is very simple - to show as close as possible to what my eyes see IRL in that moment of time I take the picture.

I do not like cameras doing their own artistic edits or takes on things in an attempt to make the image "look better". That's highly subjective and should be left as an option, not as the default - or worse - forced upon you.

I do like it when they do things that make the photo look closer to how my eyes saw the subject when taking the image, such as fixing lens distortion or white balance.

In a nutshell, I'm in favour of it for the purposes of making the image more realistic, even if it means a less "pleasing" image to some (e.g. If I take a photo of a field on a very foggy morning, I really don't want the phone removing the fog from the photo). Just don't screw around with reality please.

text: I agree with you. The comment section is full of people disturbed with the automatic image editing within the image processing software. Although I respect all their opinions, I think that most of the people don't really care about these things, and for them a good photo is a good photo regardless of whether it's edited or not. But I also think that sometimes the colours in reality are much more enticing than when the image is edited, so cameras should also be able to capture simple real images and there should be a mode for Instagram ready photos which take the most attractive image of a subject using any appropriate filter or effects.
author: @heythisisnick6908

text: Â @kshitizjha7537Â  THANK YOU! I'm always trying to make people understand that. Grew up around ACTUAL artists, ACTUALLY TALENTED photographers, with ACTUAL skills, who were gifted with talent and worked hard on the ACTUAL craft. I grew up with ACTUAL ARTISTS in my household, grew up around darkrooms, dodging and burning, and actual tiny brushes, actual ink, stuff that requires ACTUAL artistry, skills, to use for when retouching was needed. I hate this generation of dummies with a passion. Glad there are still people out there who think like you, who truly get it. Really glad.

text:
The moon thing isn't entirely correct. We all see the same side of the moon, yes, but the angle of the moon changes with your latitude. If we say that the moon is "upright" at the equator, it leans up to 90 degrees to one side going north, and to the other side going south. So if you live in the US and visit Australia, the moon will look upside down to you. 

The more you know!

text:
In my opinion, the "perfect" regular photo mode would snap an image that looks the same as our eyes would see it. Of course people differ, so it would in reality match the average eye and brain combo. 

Our eyes and brain do all sorts of enhancements on the raw image data entering our eyes. I think phones should try to achieve to mimic this.

Then phones can have an additional modes that allow you to take photos that are enhanced different or beyond this. But the regular photo mode IMO should take take a photo and apply AI to match how our eyes see.

text:
This should not only be supported but encouraged. However, the AI can't always know what we look for in a photo (it mostly does), which is why we should have the option of picking unedited photo, lightly processed photo (the details of the process chosen by us) and heavily processed photo (which is what the phone thinks looks the best), and then deleting the other two after user makes his choice, after every shot. This would be THE next big thing if it was a reality. Note that down.
Imagine a 85 year old grandma who knows nothing about photo editing, taking wonderful shots just by pointing the camera. Stuff of legends right there.

text: Prior to the invention and perfection of the film camera, every "image" of humans or landscapes or anything that exists in reality at all was an "artists interpretation" of the scene. If you think about it, the "realistic photo" era has been extremely short, really only about as long as 40 or 50 years or so, or about as long as high quality color film has been commonly available. In some respects we're returning to tradition with smart photography. We're using the cameras to create art, rather than simply record a slice of time, true to color and movement and object shapes and sizes.

The problem with camera phones is the human.

I get the idea that it is cool and all and could overcome some stigmatization, but we should love how we are too. There could be an argument that our profiles reflect who we want to be, but should we look at people based on what they could and want to be, and is it even possible to change our hairlines, noses, jaws, etc. in real life? I feel like we are going down a dangerous path where everyone will be catfishing without even knowing. I just wish the (destigmatizing) idea that looks donâ€™t matter too much was promoted first, and people could have full control of the level of beautification and or reality-bending second.
author: @avariciousaxolotl

text: Photographs, whether they be out of a smartphone, MILC, DSLR, or a film camera, have never been a completely accurate rendition of a scene. Lenses do not operate like the human eye; with set focal planes, different perspectives and projections. Shutter speeds represent motion in unrealistic ways; either being blurred or frozen in time). Colours and tones are just an interpretation by the manufacturer of digital camera or film. And this is all before we get to choices made by the photographer.

text: To be honest, I still miss the iPhone 6 camera of its non-computational camera. Since it gave the most real world physical state of lights, colour, skin tone, and even the detail of the photo is sharper than current iPhones' blurry images. The computational photography nowadays doesn't give accurate colour and lights, you would find it heavily adjusted, especially in the situation when the subject looks dark in the sunlight. I think the meaning of computational photography is to breakthrough the physical limitation of lens, so users wouldn't have to adjust the result. But if you're a more serious Instagramer, you see they'd still have to adjust the picture. So, computational photography is still a little early, when smartphone lenses can still breakthrough. Also, I'd say Google has the best computational photography as it's keeping the sharpness and colour. The iPhone is very good on videos, especially at night, but the photos are not on par and overly adjusted.

text: Great video. But I will quibble with one comment. All photos are a departure from reality. They compress a 3D space onto a 2D space, for one thing. They selectively capture light and color (as do our eyes). Ansel Adams, when asked why he never shot color (which he did for commercial work - unsigned), said that the reason he always shot black and white is because he wanted his photos to be viewed as artistic abstractions of reality and that there be no confusion of reality with his photography. He felt that even going to color would invite such comparisons. The problem, which you rightly identify, is when cameras impose their vision of reality instead of letting the photographer impose his or hers. Of course, that requires a level of technical expertise but, more importantly, the creative vision to express a photographic reality on the part of the photographer. And, youâ€™re right, most people donâ€™t want to do that. But, thatâ€™s what continues to set apart those who do (serious photographers) from those who donâ€™t. Of course, George Eastman recognized that over 100 years ago when he built the first consumer camera. Iâ€™ve been pretty good at controlling my iPhone so far but I admit my recently-acquired iPhone 13 Pro fights me a lot more than my Xs did.

text:
I think the real question is, â€œWhat is the purpose of the image, and what is it meant to communicate?â€ 

I think thatâ€™s the line that needs to be drawn. 

Obviously for the Santa Monica Instagram example, the purpose of the image is to communicate two things. 

1) The person/object present in the photo. 
2) The background itself. 

So, in that case, removing all the extra people in the background could possibly be justified.  Thatâ€™s the extent I would allow this.

It still is and will always be an interesting question though.

text: This video makes me think of the painted portraits people use to have to sit through for hours before photography was accessible. The folks requested a portrait and it was up to the artist to render the ideal image of that person even if it didn't reflect reality. If you look up different portraits of famous people from pre-1800s, portraits of the same person can look completely different depending on the artist. Same with sculptures. I think choice is most important here; give us the choice of what style we want our pictures in, whether it's completely raw or heavily edited.

text:
I wonder if computational photography could diminish the value of photos as evidence, e.g. in a legal process. 
Let's say I took a photo with a killer in the background with a gun in his hand. But the AI for some reason (security etc) removes the gun, leaving the murderer with an empty hand, thus, faking reality. 
I'm aware that this is an extreme example, but I also think that we should be able to see the ways in which an advanced, future AI "photoeditors" would edit our photos.

I don't know if this is really much of an issue, as long as the auto-editing remains limited to things like optimal color correction, brightness/shadow detail adjustments, etc. The feature you showed where you could actually edit your face with the "beauty filter" got a little closer to what we've had for decades in the magazine industry -- Models whose cover photos and ad pics were Photoshopped so heavily they bore little resemblance to the original shot in terms of removing age lines, taking away some belly fat that might have shown, or slimming down their legs and arms. But I think most people inherently reject features like that for the reasons you noted, and only influencers (and the wanna-be's) would actively use features like that. Even then, I think a lot of people would pick up on those tricks and reject the person who used them.

On a related note, what most of us have wanted in a cameraÂ going back to the earliest mass-market cameras that took Kodak film cartridges, is exactly what you roughly said at the start of the video: Something that will let us capture a memory that's "good enough", that we can share with people and relive those moments. Smartphone cameras have given the masses the ability to get incredibly polished pictures that satisfy that basic want to an incredible degree, and I'm more than happy to let the camera do that work for me so that I can just quickly take a shot that presents itself and have that memory available to share and remember without needing to fuss over it in an editor later on.

text:
The moon example is really interesting!

In regards to what is "reality," I tend to think of such discussions as moot. (My guess about understanding reality is that we are probably trying to understand something humans aren't capable of understanding, with a tool (consciousness/our brain) we don't even fully understand))

So to me, the more pertinent question is, how do you share/communicate a memory, or an idea, in an accepted way? 
The moon scenario is interesting to me in this regard. We share images we feel we have found/created (ex: discovering and sharing memes) to people who already have access (can see) the same content. More abstractly, a phrase like "I love you" is copied/pasted all the time, but it can mean many things depending on the context. So I wonder if this baked-in moon controversy boils down to what the sharer and sharee have agreed upon, and/or accepted on how to communicate.
 
As a side question, I wonder where people stand on other mediums. Each have their own variables affecting what is/isn't captured/recorded, and the interpretation of it (human perception (senses + thinking)). Do your concerns/feels about digital image processing apply to any other media? like:

film (still image and image sequences)
drawing/painting
written language
spoken (oral) language
body language and DANcE

text:
I imagine the issue is most people don't think of a picture they took as a snapshot as a piece of art but of documentation. In the more pro world, pictures always were about the vision of the photographer and way more art but I think the smart phone users is thinking more like their Polaroid of the past which was usually very documentary. We also currently often treat cellphone photos and now more videos as evidence and proof of an event. Of course, this is changing because we know you can modify stuff, but as pointed out here, right now it generally requires knowledge that you are actually modifying the image or video. 

I'm afraid these AI tools kind of make our images more like our memories as they are trying to show what we experienced vs  perhaps what we actually saw, and while that is better in some situations, also leads us to something like false memories or mistaken memories in the digital realm where we used to have a more fixed record. Maybe for court cases we'll go back to requiring Polaroid film to meet evidence standards IDK. Maybe we'll insist on all evidence to be from certified "dumb, non AI" imaging which leaves out cell phones. 

And in daily life IDK how various people will take it. I already treat a professional portrait from someone differently than a candid shot, and as our lives get ever more polished for social media consumption, I think we might cause more depression or feelings of not being as good as everyones not only curated but AI retouched and improved digital lives. I'm not sure I want the shock of my IRL friends looking so different in person from how I see them in pictures like we have with movie stars today.

text:
Dah... I'm not ok with this. This is the Twitter edit button debate. "sure sure, you found an issue and want to edit... but when is it so much of an edit that it becomes something different? And is there any way to automate the edit?". I remember in college, telling a friend that we needed a way to know an image/video was edited. Some way to say "that rando/news/gov/etc. edited the image/video that they're now showing as fact". You can think blockchain, but these are devices that aren't (and shouldn't be required) to be connected to the internet to function. What can be done? Will it be like court cameras where they are certified to not edit the image? (note: court cameras are specifically designed to not make shutter noises and only 1 or so brands are allowed to be used... but they're expensive even by DSLR standards). We already have debates about news, social media, and official statements. Humanity uses visuals and sound to convey the world we understand to others... and text, speech, sound, and increasingly video and pictures are not the fact they are believed to be. But instead of "well, I this is how I remember it" of cave paintings to stories and performances, it's closer to a Soviet-style propaganda piece, manipulated to elicit an opinion or thought. But instead of manipulating multi-national decisions, it's to get a like on a Twitter post. Hope you don't see it in court... because that's an argument that's already been made in at least one high profile case.

TL:DR-expected and not surprised by absolutely not OK with.

text:
This was interesting to see.
I had a similar fight between reality and AI-processing in February when I had to decide between an iPhone 11 Pro Max and a XS Max because I needed a successor to my 8+. In theory, the 11 was quite hyped back when it came out, but there were many occasions for me where the photos didnâ€™t just look realistic. Colour representation in indoor shots was awful, Text was sharpened like crazy that it looked like everything but what I had before my eyes. I went with the XS then as it was more realistic,  but ever since I have noticed that it f*cks up white balance in some situations and in filming videos colours tend to change because of the integrated algorithm. Since then, I started to use a third party app and now I get pretty good balanced photos under any circumstances; having compared it myself to a 12 Pro Max lately, differences in most settings (cloudy sky, not much light) were not big, but the 12 was much better at white balance on the whole, colours were quite on spot.

Getting back to the main point: I think there are some Computational features that really help to create a good image for the average user. Letâ€˜s say the iPhoneâ€˜s HDR when having bright light sources in your picture to not have a blown out spot in the photo. Or proper video stabilization without having to edit it after. But a picture is mainly the reproduction of time and space, i.e. a reproduction of something someone discovered somewhere at a given time. Cameras should reproduce this as accurately as possible, everything else can be done afterwards, be it a simple filter, be it dedicated editing or whatever. I would wish they donâ€™t push this too far but I guess the direction is already set.

text:
I think it completely depends on what your goal is with taking pictures: 
for me, 99% of the time it is to create a revisitable visual memory of a particular moment in time: a dinner at a friends, or that one night time sky on vacation, or a special moment in life. As such, I would be okay with an optimization using data taken within lets say 10 seconds of the moment of capture: you're still fixating the memory of that time, but such that it can represent it better than just one shot. Anything beyond that no longer represents that moment in time imo, and thus should not be accepted (e.g. removing people from backrgrounds or using a pretaken one)
HOWEVER, if your goal is something different, like a shot for a commercial, then sure anything is allowed, as you are creating a fictional situation anyway. 

So Im predicting different objective capturing  modes.

Just my two cents. Curious what others think

text:
This is something I've always thought about unconsciously.. It's the very basic concept between the experience of photography with a camera & in parallel the experience of editing with advanced tools mixed with a few 'cheap' tricks.
Example: You take a photo of your early walk through a park filled with trees, fallen leaves, and the occasional person sitting, reading. In the frame is everything I just described but a random bird just pooped a few feet ahead of you lol. The poop is obvious. Yet it's a part of the natural environment so how do you approach it? You can leave it. You can modify it by a) crop the photo b) mask the area* c) cover the 'area' with a mask however it's only going to use the texture surrounding it. It cannot regenerate something from a pre-existing asset. **.

By pre-existing asset, it's like the example shown of the moon on the phone in the video. It's not using a piece of information from the surface of the moon, rather aligning the shape & projecting it the same way many puppy/cat ears track your face with a filter. Except, on the environment.
I got lost in the tangent but if you've made it this far - you're beautiful/awesome. In the example I tried to bring up its that you can have a blend of both the organic elements of a photo & the enhancement with AI where the slider on that AI can only work within what's in the photo & not use another/outside source of information to replace something entirely.

text: When i go to the park and stuff to take photos, I don't want AI to change any part of my photo to make it look good. I want to remember that moment as it was, looking back I want to recall the things that happened that day, and having software edit that automatically is just unhelpful at the very least. I want to see companies give you an option if you want your smartphone to do that in the phone setup that is by default switched off. As reality blends into virtual, we lose control of our memories, our everyday lives. In certain ways AI can refine moments well and when wanted, but enough is enough and we shouldn't be letting AI take over. It's like Meta, where it sounds really good, but you don't want to engage yourself in it because you fear you will lose the control you currently have over your real life, but then again, it's just the next level of social media and we already accept social media into our lives. Maybe this type of tech will be accepted by the next generation, but I still want to be able to see the line between reality and VR
author: @_wandering

text:
Honestly I'm fine with it. Why? If we take a step back, these pictures are meant to be enjoyed by "regular" people and created by "regular" people. Photographers are will always want more control because they want their vision to come out. Realistic/Abstract/Something in between, they want to show people what they see in their head. 

A lot of regular people, just want a good looking photo to post. They care about what the photo triggers ( good or bad) in others, versus what the photo contains, and how close the photo is to reality. 

I'm not even gonna get into how social media photos are already curated/highlights of life and a non-trivial amount of steps away from reality of the situation.

author: @dIancaster

text: Â @dIancasterÂ  But have you ever taken like 10 photos of an event, gone home and seen them and they were NOT at all how you imagined them, and you wouldn't post them anywhere, let alone show them to your friends? I think the point is, that these features help the photos match your expectations of how the photos, were gonna turn out, not "Reality". You don't want a photograph of you in a suit at a wedding for documenting a realistic perception of the world, you want a photograph of you, because you expect to look good and of course want that to last. Also, you don't experience an unfiltered reality, and you especially don't remember it that way. My point being that in a way, these altered photos better match experience than the "real" ones.

text: I think it's a weird spot. On one hand I would ask "why are we so precious about pictures?" This is already done with our music and TV Shows and Movies. The drums you hear? Not real drums. Half the guitars you hear? Simulated on a computer. Singer? Never off-key thanks to pitch correction. Guitar solos? Let's take the best parts of the 10 solos you recorded and make one super amazing solo. They edit multiple takes of a scene together in movies and TV shows. Edit and change takes on voiceovers. The sound of leaves crunching under foot? Those sounds weren't recorded then, they were added later via foley engineers, hell they might not even BE sounds from leaves. The phones are simply doing what we would do after the fact in "real time". Yes, it removes some of the artistry of hand-editing. But there's still artistry in framing and composition. It just opens the door to more people enjoying the photographs they take and in the end in more photographs being taken.

text:
Beautifying is a potentially psychologically dangerous thing to have as an 'Automatic' thing to have. Yes, the Chinese markets have had this for some years now, and modelling magazines for decades before that, but, it is pushing, nay, reinforcing the younger generations expectations of 'What should be' with regards to their self image, making 'Fake' the norm, making 'Fake' the necessary image to present to everyone else... When really, loving who you are, what you look like SHOULD be the primary objective.... So when a natural picture/image is, accidentally/maliciously leaked online, the amount of psychological trauma that can be had sadly can, and does lead to suicides...
But hey, what does this 50 year old Brit bloke know? I've only watched this happen over my years and seen the effects of this develop over time, and my voice means nothing to the younger generations, as, "It's not important, current or the in thing". Honesty, respect, and decency have been replaced with greed, selfishness, fake self image and delusions of self grandeur....

text:
Okay so my take is this:
- Features like the Pixel ones where you can choose a good photo out of 10, are genuinely useful. Try to photograph a kid without it. The great thing about it is, you have all the dials. It doesn't lie to you or hide the details. It's just like, here, this might help, also you can use it as a short video, or not use it at all.
- Features where it changes the colors or the saturation or overlays a pre-existing image over the real one are downright creepy IMO. I want my photos to reflect the reality. Maybe allow me to do what you're offering IF i want to but most importantly allow me to disable, or better yet, don't enable it by default.

I guess it's more about whether the objective of the feature is assisting you in selection and taking accurately exposed and stable pictures, or lying to you so you get a more "pleasing" reality with no possibility of turning it off.

text: While Iâ€™ve only read through several dozen comments, it is interesting to me how many people feel that at "some point" in photographyâ€™s history, photographs represented a captured reality. As a person who has studied photography in college and at university, it is my understanding that photography has never duplicated reality. There have been processes that people feel are realistic and these have been accepted as a representation of our understanding of reality; however, our minds are fooling themselves. It comes down to what a photograph is. It is a flat 2D rendering of a 3D space captured from a static perspective. What Iâ€™m trying to convey is that our minds actually provide any sense of reality we may perceive in an image. Does that really change if AI is giving most viewers the "reality" the want to see?

text:
The key difference here is that it's happening without most people realizing that it does. Taking photos with a film camera would have effect on the captured image, and people were aware that life wasn't sepia-toned or had a varying color palette. 
The AI modifying facial features or smoothening out things without you realizing it, could have drastic effects on people's self-perceptions or perceptions of reality. 
It is also an issue of it's not exactly a reality that many viewers want to see either, it has the biases of the creator of the AI system influencing it too. 
It could also be used more nefariously, to peddle certain make up products etc.

text:
Nearly two years of pandemic have meant a lot of us not going out as often as we would. We have all been connected via social media, where due to the increasing AI features in our phones, we can sell a false image of what we really look like(earlier on social media, we were already selling a false image of what we felt like). The distortion to reality is well underway.

I imagine in future, people would just exist in the social media space. People who look extremely "appealing" due to all kinds of AI manufacturing their bodies. You have gained unhealthy weight? Just use AI to remove it. Natural blemishes on face? You can already remove those. Imagine the devastating consequences this will bring to the self images and esteem of people with impressionable minds.

It's like plastic surgery, but much better, at a fraction of the cost, and extremely immediate. Say goodbye to delayed gratification and consequently to working towards achieving your goals! All this has the potential to dent the social fabric in ways never seen before.

text: So prior to owning a Pixel, my standard for a camera on a phone was pretty darn low.  Now I'm not a photograhy buff.  So my thought was always, as long as it's seems fairly accurate that's good enough.  To me other aspects of the phone were much more important.  After owning the original and more so after owning the Pixel 3 that changed.  I just felt like those pictures were always just better, I didn't even understand why at first.  Soon after getting my Pixel 3 this is several years ago I'm with a friend who is a photography buff and an iPhone owner and of course do to the Pixel camera hype he wanted to check it out.  Of course he was immediately impressed but he also kinda pointed out exctly what was happening.  He's basically told me "Thing is these photos look like the've already been edited."  And he kinda pointed out that's why the Pixel seemed to have the  "better" camera, it's not necessarily the most realistic like a RAW  photo file, but it was making really good choices to enhance the photo.  He was pretty impressed at the time.  Obviously now a few years later other companies seem to be catching up.  I will say this, I have a Pixel 6 on order, and I've kinda been disappointed with the current Samsung S21 I have because of it's camera which I feel needs multiple shots to get a "good" shot or many times I have to run through the built in photo editor or Snapseed.  But it's odd because prior to owning a Pixel that wasn't so important to me.  But yes the smarter camera is probably the better camera for average consumer.  Although it does beg the question how smart is too smart?!?  Hopefully real photographers are still out there to remind us what the real world looks like haha.

text: Thanks for bringing this up. These features are mostly very useful, but the fact that they don't make any effort to let us know what's happening is disturbing indeed. Photos are meant to be "captures" of the moment. That is an implicit contract. Messing with that capture without even telling you is a breach of that contract. And the fact that my eye in FaceTime was replaced with another one without my knowledge for two major iOS versions, well, that is worth freaking out about a bit.

text: Am I ok with cameras spitting out "finished" images that are further and further from reality? I'd say yes! Our brain does it, all the time..... to some extent, sometimes you glance over at something and your brain constructs an image based on the little information that it had, then you turn around, look at it again and realize it wasn't what you thought it was. Or hallucinations are basically your brain merging 2 or more images (from different sources) together (well not exactly, more like an equivalent of merging). As long as we have scientific instruments aka cameras that take as realistic photos as possible (or do as little manipulation as possible) then cameras can take generated and artificially enhanced photos! :)

full auto - gives the picture it thinks you'd like to see
manual - lets you adjust different settings that appear depending on the context
semi auto - remembers adjustments you make and automatically applies them
default - takes the most accurate photo; what a person would see
raw - stores all data for photo editors

text:
Letting the public vote on which photos look better will have a huge bias. Like you said, every manufacturer has their own idea of what a picture should look like, and users will start to get used to that. Since most people have iphones and therefore get used to seeing their iphone photos as the standard, they will be more biased (on average) to choose the iphone photos when asked which one is better. 

This actually goes a lot further than just pictures with no personal editing. HDR has been overused for so long and passed off as good editing to the general public that people are starting to truly believe that way too much HDR actually looks like a higher quality photo. Smartphone manufacturers and social media apps are skewing the public opinion on what looks good and now people are much more likely to say that terribly over-edited photos are actually high quality. 

I can't tell you how many "professional photographers" who get paid a lot of money to do photoshoots use auto mode on their DSLR and put the same filter on all of their photos in post regardless on the type of setting, theme, or type of photo. And they get praised for it! The photos themselves aren't even that good in the first place. A good editor with a RAW image still couldn't even make it look good but still people are convinced that the photos are good because they have been trained to think that through sites like facebook and instagram as well as their camera apps on their phones editing their pictures without them knowing it.

text:
Here's another thought to think about. We've been doing for decades with print and tv. We already know the dangers that it can cause on society and perception of beauty among other topics. A lot of the times, although the technology is cool, there's never the ethical study on what it does to society.

I'm not saying get rid of AI or even filters, but maybe smart folks out there can think about ways to let people know if and when photos or videos are enhanced or some way to identify authenticity. There's always going to be workarounds to this such as good old tricks with wearing vertical stripes versus horizontal to trick the eye, or even just plain simple makeup tricks so maybe the point is mute and the problem is not tech, but people wanting to look better.

At the end of the day, I would just like these companies to think about giving me an option to turn things on and off and not assume they know what a user would want. =)

text:
So, what you're saying is: we need transparency?

Joke aside, I'd argue that having the unvarnished/unmanipulated image/record be retained alongside (or even within) the manipulated result, and that it also be referenced by the manipulated result somehow. Having the ur-image retained and referenced in this way should be a standard, required protocol.
author: @michaelthibault7930

text: If each frame was serialized with a time stamp this would be a potential way to verify originality, albeit a super data intensive one. Also, if these were automatically signed on a blockchain, weâ€™d have more solid confidence in the data.

text: We need free and open source software (as in free speech) that we have control. If the phone could detect objects and send it to the phone maker, then our privacy is threatened.
author: @wongjowo9152

text: Â @BrettWrightsPageÂ  sounds good, but to have confidence you need validated hardware and validated image pipeline too. digitally signing frames and storing the hash in block chain only can prevent after the fact edits, but can't prevent preprocessing or processing in general. garbage in, garbage out
author: @mtx33

text: Â @mtx33Â  Great point on the hardware. What would validated hardware even look like? Is it possible to validate something in the real world as well as digital signatures?
author: @BrettWrightsPage

text: â€‹ @Brett Wright  i have no idea, maybe a tamper proof casings with self destructing private keys in a battery backed memory chip, assembled and sealed in a factory you trust (certification etc.), like how they make the portable credit card readers or how they store(d) the signing keys in a tamper proof encased pci card in some big banks. Or if you need less security maybe something like what they did on the consoles with digitally signed firmware (trusted computing). You can embedded the private keys inside the processor, so without extreme expensive lab equipment you has no chance to extract it and let the processor to validate all components serial number which the factory programmed after assembly. But if there is some software bug, the whole process can be jeopardized. (jailbreaking) Not speaking about that if somebody can manufacture a custom sensor (if they can circumvent the serial checking) to fake the physical image, or put a fake screen in front of the camera that can fool the sensor, etc. I think with unsupervised physical access and adequate resources, you can't trust the hardware 100%. The question is what security level we want to achieve, and how high we can put the bar.

text:
My take is this: The way I use my smartphone camera and the way I use an "actual" camera will always be very different.

 When I take a shot with my "actual" camera I'm thinking about light, aperture, exposure, composition, focus, and countless other little factors that I want control over. If I'm shooting on film there's even more careful thought and planning, I'm spending at l very least 2-3 minutes setting up a shot. What I am trying to end up with is not an accurate representation of the scene, but rather an artistic vision of it. When I get the images on my computer, I don't go straight to posting -- I spend time deciding on colors, removing distracting objects or people, finding the right crop. The image  is a production that takes hours. It is less about the scene depicted and more about the piece of art as a whole.
 
In contrast, when I take a picture with my phone I want to quickly capture a fleeting moment in time. Maybe my cats did something funny, maybe I'm proud of a meal I just cooked, maybe I want to record a good day out with friends. The goal is not to make lengthy artistic decisions and end up with something I'd be happy to hang on my wall, it's to get something that looks as good as possible and captures the memory as well as possible without having to fuss over it. I'm still willing to edit the photo a bit if it didn't come out how I wanted it to, but most of the time it just gets posted without any changes. This is why I chose the pixel because 90% of the time it produces a stunning shot that looks great to post right away, and the 10% it doesn't I'm happy to go back and edit it until I'm happy. Very rarely does a shot simply not turn out at all -- an especially stark contrast to film photography.

I view all of the computational advancements in smartphone photography as a very good thing for artists, because it opens up much more mental space for creativity with my other cameras. When I leave the house with my Mamiya or Lumix, I'm doing it because I intend to look for interesting moments, I'm aiming to create something not necessarily tied to the thing I am taking a picture of. My smartphone camera is not like that, it's something that's there when I need it, something I can quickly pull out and use to capture the time my cat fell in bowl of cranberry sauce, or make a quick video to send to my brother.

I will say that these categories are not universally clear cut, there's certainly some crossover between them. Especially with the Pixel's powerful portrait mode, I occasionally find myself really fussing over a shot in the same way I would with my other cameras. Sometimes I'm looking back through my camera roll and I see a shot the makes me think "Wow! I couldn't have done that on the Mamiya". But that state of focus that largely divides the two formats in my mind is extremely important. It's one of the reasons why film photography is having a resurgence despite digital being technically superior in nearly every way. The device you use to take a picture impacts how much you think about the image you're taking, and that in turn affects what image you end up with. It's a mistake to say smartphones are making us worse photographers, they just make us different photographers.

There will always be a disconnect between that and people who prefer that control and who are photographers.

How far are we from removing someone from the scene of the crime automatically because the AI thought they were ruining the shot?  Or that the blood splatter was a blemish that needed corrected?  I understand that with where the tech is now its not unsolvable by smart people, but it does seem like it moving in that direction.

text: Aaaaaaaaaah! (Screaming at screen) I am SOoOoO glad that you brought up this issue with the iPhone!!! I dabble in astrophotography and this year I purchased an excellent pair of binoculars and a Celestron 3-Axis Smartphone Adapter to capture long exposure images with the telephoto lens on my iPhone 11pro. I quickly learned that the iPhone kept choosing a different lens and I the phone was lying about what lens I was using. After a long search I also learned that there was NO OPTION for the user to CHOOSE to toggle this function off. My Christmas wish is that the option to turn off this auto switch could be added in a firmware update.       Cheers!   -Jonathan

text:
An iPhone camera horror story ...

I found a situation, in which, the iPhone 13 pro camera, produces a horror story of picture. No exaggeration. It entirely destroyed the picture taken. I may could share this with Marques if interested and not sharing the picture publicly but perhaps reproducing it.

Short description: medium light room, left wall with a texture on and the direct other wall entirely with mirror. then put a person in front of the mirror. take a picture against the mirror of the person and make sure half of the wall with the texture is also in the picture. What happened is that the iPhone distributed the texture from the wall over the part of the entire mirror and over the person. It just recognises a pattern an put this pattern all over ... even over the faces and clothing. It looked absolutely freaky.

text: How do you define "your interpretation"? What happens when "your interpretation" is shaped/influenced by how these cameras portray you? Personally, I prefer the most raw image that stays true to reality (while having the option to edit)
author: @Loading-lg6hs

text:
Â @Loading-lg6hsÂ  the point is still "what is reality"? If you talk about "objective reality" then there is much the camera could see that our eyes filter out including infrared/ultraviolet wavelengths, it's just beyond our capabilities, but still belongs to the objective reality of what light is bouncing off the object. If you mean "human perception", then even this differs between individuals, since our eyes are not all equal and calibrated to each other, even just in the physical visual sense, we all perceive slightly different images. And again that's dismissing the many emotional factors that have a significant impact on how our brain builds and curates and filters the reality we perceive.

When i say "my interpretation", i mean that i look at the image, and within the error margins i accept of my perception of the image vs the phone screen colour calibration vs an Instagram viewer's phone calibration vs their own visual perception (a lot of visual gateways this image is going through)... If i look at it and can accept that "it looks like the moment looks/feels to me, which has caused me to want to record/share it in the first place" then the image matches "my interpretation".

text: As a photographer, I feel computational photography is a terrifying prospect. The exactitude with which cameras record their subject is fundamental to the photographic medium. obviously digital photos have allowed for more advanced manipulation of that data however having artificial intelligence to automatically fix every possible issue with a photo threatens that bedrock on which photography sits. "The capacity for mechanical inscription and the order of direct reference that links the photograph with the indisputable fact of its subjectâ€™s existence are the bedrock of photography and film" - Okwui Enwezor, 2019.

text:
I think the question that concerns me the most about this topic, is "Should photos taken by certain smartphones be inadmissible in a court of law as evidence due to the fact that the AI could have done editing on faces or other components of the environment?"

We've kind of lived with spruced up faces for a little while on social media, and I don't think it's any more damaging than social media has already been which is no small amount. 

However, if a smartphone has the capability to generate a photograph that misrepresents an event then that could be very damaging for an innocent person being charged with a crime they didn't commit. 

Likewise, evidence that could convict a guilty person may be considered inadmissible because of the potential that the image was altered by the phone. I think it's a very interesting challenge that we might see at some point at least here in the United States.

text:
Consider:  You mentioned the case where the AI "recognizes" a popular Instagram wall.  Well, it also has GPS coordinates, so it could easily look up whatever popular landmarks are at your location.  The AI/machine-learning part doesn't have to compare your photo to a million images of walls around the planet, it only has to compare what is sees to maybe a dozen images that would make sense to see at your location.
And if you think "that's still an awful lot of data", well, there's also an awful lot of data in the street view of Google maps.

text: Really tho this is only "weird" if one looks as photography as being intrinsically capable of capturing "optical reality" which really is a relatively recent phenomenon (if it is true at all). Earliest photographic processes had such long exposure time the only ones who could get a perfectly clear photo of themselves are dead people, colour photography didn't become common place until the last quarter of the 20th century, and not to mention once we shifted to the early version of mass market digital photography we practically dialled it back a couple of decades in terms of image resolution. Photography has always been about pushing the boundaries of our visual senses and let us see what we otherwise couldn't in person. It's really interesting to see smartphones now unlocking the next frontier in what photography can show us.

text: It's gone too far. They're trying to push the limits of small sensors with all the computational stuff and yes, the results are great in that context, although far from any sense of accurate. Try taking a shot from a 3rd party camera app that doesn't use the smarts, like Lightroom. You get what the sensor captured, warts and all (and there are a lot of warts). What they're doing is really clever and often looks very good. My Nikon Zs do way better without computational smarts; but who, every day, wants to carry a large lump of expensive non-pocket friendly tech that just does one thing?

text: This is... Not correct. Optical zoom is always superior to digital zoom regardless of the situation. The only benefit would be digitally zooming on a lens that has a wider aperture, but this means less sharpness so when you zoom in on the softer image, it's still just as fuzzy. If you are thinking brightness=quality, sure, but it doesn't. I would love to see an example of a photo where digital zoom looked better than optical. We're also talking about tiny lenses that are within fractions of aperture stops of one another. There's no benefit to digital.

text:
Â @armchaircritechÂ  there are no cameras that will show you reality as it really "is", or at least the way you see it, which in itself is very subjective, color blind people see reality very differently from non color blind people, and that doesn't make it "less real", the same way there are animals that can see colors humans can't.
Cameras are nowhere near as good as human eyes, that's why we might want some HDR to be able to better see what's in the shadows, which could be something you can see perfectly in real life but the camera can't. It's the same with color, every camera processes color differently, and it might be very far off from the way your eyes see color in reality, so that's why one would want to edit a photo to "make it look more real"

That being said, there is a huge difference between playing with shadows and color and changing your hairline or making your eyes bigger, that's straight up distortion of reality
author: @S0KE

text: Â @armchaircritechÂ  most images you take them with the largest range of colors and enough exposure or not too much exposure because color may be washed out when we want the most details in an image especially in an environment with suboptimal lighting. At that point youâ€™d want to add your own perspective of color or what reality should have looked like if youâ€™re color blind or impaired. Some color blind people do a twist on photography which in itself is beautiful

Then, gradually, it started do be more automated and smart, with things like automatic transmission, ABS, traction control, stability control, tire pressure level sensors, oil change reminders, automatic headlights in the dark, automatic wipers when raining, and lots more.

Being different is what makes the world an interesting place

text:
Great thoughts nicely articulated as usual, but we gotta remember that social media never was & never will be a way to really know people, it's within reason to expect that every profile is a carefully orchestrated view of a person's identity or place, what they want people to see and not necessarily what is, and that's fine. If you want to really know people you need to interact with them more than that.

The problem here is, like others mentioned & Marques highlighted, you don't get any control. So you might wanna capture an actual moment, say for evidence of something bad happening, but then the camera edits that photo to the point that it's not reliable as evidence of any sort coz nothing about it would look natural. It's even hard to tell the time of day nowadays with crazy night modes that look like day & whatnot. Smartphones might be getting crazier & better, but it seems like they can never really replace real big optical cameras, at best just a substitute product for diff use cases.

text:
I think you answered your own question: smartphone cameras becoming smarter are just doing what the 'pros' have been doing for years when they photoshop images. They're helping the masses level up their image tuning skills. I think that's a good thing, but people likely won't even realise it's happening...and that's not great. 

I would say increased awareness is a must. It would be great if camera systems showed info on each image letting you know what edits it went through, a sort of 'edit history' that anyone can view (maybe it's in the meta data?). Imagine it had some sort of % change the image underwent, or 'reality correction %'. Might help people keep some grip on reality if they could see this sort of data. 

But how long until the same image processing is applied to everything via smart AR glasses..? Reality is rapidly becoming what our devices make it.

text:
I'd like to bring the question here even further. 
I think we got a misconception of what "the best photo" is back when Photoshop made it onto the scene. 
The "best photo" should not be the "best looking photo", so it's not matter of whose control is over tuning. The best photo, theoretically speaking, should be a 1:1 mapping of the current camera view, hence infinite pixels each one mapping to infinite geometrical points in reality. We kind of had this, with non-digital cameras, a part from lens distortion, shutter imperfections and so on. Go and check out your old family photos, they'll look particularly pleasant to your eyes, trust me.
What we can have now, of course, is not infinite pixels. What we should aim for, though, what we shall call "best photo" is the one having the max number of pixels possible, minimizing the loss function of each pixel over color, shape, position wrt the corresponding region in reality. That is, the photo which resembles the actual scene the most.
Note how this does not generally mean the best looking photo. Instead, this is most of the time false. We got used to doped, fake image (and sound, TBH) quality and now struggle to get out of that.

text:
In 9/10 cases the phone actually does NOT know best when switching to the digital zoom instead of optical.
Especially since Apple increased the f-stop on the telephoto on the 11 Pro, the telephoto in fact takes brighter and ALWAYS better pictures than the main sensor. That's because the physical opening is MUCH bigger than the main sensor. It's only "smaller" on paper. Because that's how the f-stop gets calculated. The Telephoto will take batter pictures every single time but Apple still thinks that at really dark scenarios it has to switch. And I hate it. It has become much better and as long as I don't use night mode, it rarely switches to digital zoom but still. 

It's annoying that there isn't an option like they just added for the ultra-wide on the 13 Pro... give me the damn option to ALWAYS use optical!

text:
And this is why I can wait to switch back to a Sony Xperia phone. My original Xperia Z died last year, and in a rushed purchase, I got a Samsung A51. Not the top of the line, but still, 7 years apart of camera development and tech and to my surprise, colours are always saturated, zoomed pictures look like a oil or pastel painting (no pixel definition), and I can't use burst mode at night because the phone can't process it well enough. Meanwhile, my old pal, with all the faults it had, wouldn't even second guess anything I would point to it, including burst mode at night. Were they perfect night shots? Off course not, but it still did it and as it was fireworks, I have that memory saved. If I wanted to fake some for Instagram, I want to do it on my own terms, but for me it's the closed eyes, the weird expression, the slight out focus that makes the experience real. 
 Nowadays, every active social media claims to embrace imperfections, every person is unique and beautiful in their own way... But they work actively to hide said imperfections at the same time, which is ironic, if not hypocrisy, and  the most popular phone companies just follow along with it, with maybe a couple of exceptions.

text: The thing is we never really know what is "really" happening. Our brain already does a lot of this kind of processing, so who says that one shot is more true to life than another? I actually think cameras that just gather light and record it are less true to life. I remember when I was first doing photography in high school on a K1000 and my photos never looked how I saw them. I realized at some point that higher dynamic range, pupil dilation, stitching in-focus and out-of-focus areas together, colour correction, etc. were all happening in your brain. It gets even weirder when you take temporal perception into account. I think one of human's biggest conceits is that we know what "reality" is. I think deep down we know this is a conceit and that's why we get so sensitive when our notion of reality is challenged. You might think of some scientific reality, where we are keeping a photon record within a certain frequency range, but photos will never display this very well. A photo and our viewing of it will always be a projection of some higher fidelity data source onto our subjective experience. Think of that blue/gold dress phenomenon. That was a photo. The manipulations don't end after a final image has been produced.

author: @Nooumy

text: Outside the legal complications, I feel like something important is being lost.  I regularly notice on social apps that some friends never post a 'real' photo of themselves anymore, it's quite genuinely to the point where I'm no longer sure of what they actually look like.  I'm of a different generation, but I've observed a steep and almost drastic change in the importance of appearance.  Be it from taking selfies in cool places, to transposing a fake view of your family's life onto a social media account, with carefully tailored video and photo.  Another thing I've noticed, which at first seems unrelated, is a change in attitude to alcohol in younger adults from when I was their age.  It initially felt like a good thing, not drinking as much is a positive, but it was the reasons for this change that concerned me. Again this is just my localized observation, but when I did some digging, one of the main reasons was fear of being recorded drunk, doing something embarrassing and having that permanently associated with them on social media for the rest of their lives.  This was a shock realization for me.  I did some pretty daft stuff both sober and drunk in my 20s, nothing illegal or malicious or that harmed others, but stuff that would embarrass me, put me in a negative light.   The thought that if I had done any of that today, it would stay with me forever was quite sobering (pun intended).  So all this image adjustment is part of this, what I feel is a primarily toxic culture.  But, I don't think the photography tech is the problem, sure it may undermine creative photography because people stop learning how to manipulate images manually, but it's more about the reason people are using these tools, too many of our kids are using them to conform to lie, to make their life and body look like what society says it should.  This cannot be healthy for us, and it concerns me.  I don't think censoring this tech is the answer (it's mostly cool stuff if used appropriately), rather tackling the social media problem, where many of these fake life images are created and pushed onto people.  Life is about moments, moments of perfection, moments of heartache, moments of laughter, for me that is what great photography is, capturing those moments as they happen, not artificially creating them in accordance with the trends of social media and society.

text: I am a little worried about smartphone photos becoming more and more not reality. Because, sorry to get "political", as we saw with the Kyle Rittenhouse trial, it opens the door for prosecutors/defense to question whether photo/video evidence taken via smartphone is accurate and thus admissible in court and that's really scary considering how much stuff comes to light solely because someone had a smartphone photo/video of an incident. I hope that if smartphones continue down this route they have some metadata in the photos to tell what was changed in the photo. Or that there's a magic Raw/JPG simultaneous capture that is just on by default, so that if it actually came down to a court case, the original untouched, no AI, version of the photo/video is available. Unrealistic ask, i know.

text:
I know it's not the point, but why is no one pointing out that the moon actually looks different depending on where you are on earth? As an extreme example, the moon looks upside down to someone in Australia compared to someone in Canada.


That aside, I think because there are legal ramifications to these photos being altered automatically as they're taken, the phones should save two copies of the pictures internally. One that's been enhanced and one that's untouched. Of course, with the option of disabling either one. That way if someone is taking pictures for "documentary" purposes or evidence, there is no question that it is unedited. There should be a locked entry in the EXIF data as well, if possible.

text:
I think, looking at smartphones as an experienced wedding photographer, there are huge upsides and huge downsides to the additional processing going on under the hood. Lets say at a wedding, I'd shooting group shots. I'll shoot a lot because I can't trust people to actually look at the camera with their eyes open. If I'm lucky, maybe 1 in 5 photo's will be usable. With a phone that's selecting only frames with open eyes, that's obviously going to increase that hit to miss ratio. On the flip side, the overly aggressive focus that phones have on maximum dynamic range in all scenes (especially on the iphone!) is usually the giveaway that you're looking at a smartphone image. Generally, it's a look that beginner photographers go for, but over time, you'll generally learn that controlling that dynamic range is how you achieve depth in your photo's. I've been on trips where I've shot a whole set of landscape photos on my main body, and then a whole extra set in DNG from my phone (I have a xiomi mi note 10), and generally, the results are fairly comparable. Yes, the phone has noisier and softer images, but you quickly realise how big of an advantage it is to have real control over your photos.

Just as an addition, I'm dead against that features that allow users to change their features. All it does is reinforce to people that they aren't good enough as they are. Very dangerous, and even more so for younger minds!

text:
I think the most serious implications will be psychological. Online identity that has nothing to do with reality is already a problem - we all want to look happy on our vacation photos on Facebook. We choose what we present to everyone else to paint a false picture of who we are, in fact - of who we want to be perceived as. It's just a selection of information, and yet it has serious implications, especially for teenagers. With this technology slowly creeping in, it won't be just selection - it'll be a transmogrification of what one can present.
More lies to obscure the reality. More tools to feed your false identity.
I fear the younger generations that grow up with these technologies won't be capable of perceiving the issues it creates.

text:
Observing the trends in the development of the AI industry, we can move in the direction of:
First, to improve the clarity of the picture (Reducing noise, increasing sharpness, reducing blurriness, expanding the dynamic range)
Then the replacement of things (Remove unnecessary objects from the picture, change the sky, overlay objects on the surface, change lighting)

However, in terms of quality, it will still be clear that AI was used in the photo (Unless of course the image simply does not compress the social network) since for a high-quality result of the work of neural networks, good computing power is needed)

And after all I don't mind of all of that since you need less things to care about to be able to freeze moment as best as possible. But of course, only if there would be full manual mode.

I think I'm totally okay with this. Our brain remembers moments in the exact same way a smartphone camera with AI will do. The brain doesn't store all the details of a past event, only the ones really 'good' or 'bad' ones. These companies are fine-tuning their cameras not because they can, but because we want our photos and memories to look a certain way.

text:
As a photographer, one of the most common things I encounter, especially with younger clients, is that they would prefer the picture (selfie) taken on their smartphone compared to the pictures I took with perfect lightning and editing. Mostly because my edit still shows them as they actually are and not how they wish to be seen. 
So I can only imagine this technology will keep moving forward because it is what people want nowadays, they don't want the real thing, they want an image that complies with today's superficial standards. I take a lot of pictures on my phone myself, but I turn all the automatic AI features off to somewhat have control. But I understand completely the need of just snapping a picture you're happy with without editing, I just feel they should remain somewhat "Realistic" :-)

text:
Yes, I have the same thing. I'm doing a wedding, taking candid & posed shots from the guest at the reception. People stop me "Can you take a picture" and I ready my camera... "no no, with my phone". And indeed, everyone looks "better" (according to IG/FB/TikTok standards) in that photo. And when I take a photo myself with my actual camera, some want to see the result and they go like "aargh I'm so ugly". And they do prefer the ones taken by the smartphone. The phones soften the skin, especially in low light, for starters. Not only because they look better/younger, but also because they look like everyone else on social media. Which is kinda ridiculous if you think about it. What's even more ridiculous, is the fact that people, real people at that very moment, you know, the people you talk to and have fun with, see their realistic version at that moment, not the AI-improved version. But apparently that's less important. How crazy is that. I'm thinking this will all only get worse in the future. I have feeling that people seeing their nateral self (even with full blown make-up), will be the new "nude", and the AI filtered, improved versions will be the new "dressed" in the minds of future generations. Also don't underestimate the trend on plastic surgery to make people actually look like filter X on TikTok. But that's a different discussion.

I clearly try not to spend too much thoughts about it.

author: @napolitain

text:
Oh my shit, I can relate to this so much.

I like to edit my photos to have a little flair in coloring but ultimately still look grounded in reality so no ultra blue skies or searing reds.
So I take this amazing portrait, its like perfect in my eyes, focus on point, the lighting is just right, and the afternoon colors just seeping in from the window feeling cozy.

Then I hand over the photo later and while they politely thank me for it, I can't help but notice how they seem show more excitement at their phone selfies.
Even some people have asked me to up the saturation and contrast to the detriment of the photo.
It's especially discouraging when I saw my friend lose out on a photography contest to a generic oversaturated and oversharpened collection of photos.

Art is very subjective I know, but sometimes I feel lost on whether to just follow through with what I've learned or just mimic the style of smartphone photos since people seem to react more positively to that style.
