author: @zinelabidineturki3670

text:
Â @adamalarcon4973Â  It's frustrating sometimes, but I believe people hire you for your style and skill. It's something that I always repeat clearly during my meetings with couples. They have my portfolio, they see the samples I brought with me. They know what to expect. If for some reason, the client is unhappy, because they expected "smartphone photos, but bigger" or whatever, that's not on me.
But I have a feeling, people see both "sources" as two seperate things and in my case, they still appreciated the final output I delivered. But indeed, they do appreciate the wave of smartphone material during their wedding - although I had some couples who prefered nobody took photos or video, which I understand too.

The same thing happens when I do (or did, these days...) the occasional event or nightlife assignment. I have witnessed the clear shift from "oh there's photographer, that's cool, let's just continue to have fun and he'll capture us having fun and we'll see the results in a couple of days" to ... (from miles away) "Oh a photographer. No he wants to take a photo when I'm not posing. Stop him. Let's ask him to take posed group shot from us, completely standing still and having our most trained smiles, while everone around us is dancing and having fun". And then sometimes they want me to redo it with their phone. Because, obviously, I can only show them the un-edited version of my RAW file. And then I see the same bunch taking selfies and live streams from them making funny faces, pulling each others cheeks, spilling drinks.... and what not. And sharing them with everyone else on the internet, instantly.

Of course it's better or worse on different gigs. But that very obvious shift happened in about 5-8 years. I'm not saying everything comes down to those evil smartphones, but it has attributed to it greatly. One things for sure, I enjoy the rare occasions when it does come together. The light, the vibe and people letting me do my thing.

author: @nezunish-2-824

text: Â @prestonageÂ  I thought it was that the prosecutor couldnâ€™t produce an expert witness to prove the image is not altered after zoomed and enhanced in short notice? I donâ€™t think it was rejected completely
author: @tommykong89

text: Â @tommykong89Â  Right, it seemed that if an expert on the algorithm testified positively the evidence would have been allowed, but it was a concern in the first place because the pixels are altered and not scaled linearly. They could have just just scaled the footage linearly, and it wouldn't have been an issue, but it goes to show how tiny things can affect legal cases, and the stuff in this video is not tiny.
author: @prestonage

text: Â @prestonageÂ  There was a lengthy debate about it, but it was eventually accepted into evidence. And it was a drone footage, so most likely an action camera, not a cellphone camera. And whether bicubic alters the image to the point it doesn't reflect reality is a moot point when you're displaying it on a 4K TV with an image processing pipeline. For all those reasons, pixel peeping should not be accepted as legal evidence, because even if you use nearest point with an integer multiplication zoom and use a monitor, the camera still has behind the scene processing.

text:
Superimposing the same picture of the Moon? Have you heard about moon phases? Also, the reason why most pictures of the Moon look like a shiny blob is because of light metering, phones just do a whole frame metering and take the average, which means super bright spots on a super dark background look awful. You can try switching to spot metering and point on the moon itself, if the camera you're using can actually do that, and presto, nice looking Moon images.
Also i know this "i shoot RAW and then edit my pictures, cause ooc jpegs are crap" mentality looks very sexy and professional, but it is utterly arrogant as well to think that some random bloke buying a phone will have a better grasp on exposure, colour science and editing than the professional who do this for a living at a major imaging company. It would be similar to "i'm not watching a finished version of this movie, i'll do my own editing to the shots".

text:
I practice traditional photography as a hobby so I have mixed feelings about this. On one hand it's nice to pull out my wizard's slab-O-glass and be able to snap off some quick shots that will almost always look great. Being able to concentrate on just the composition alone is great and for me, messing around in manual mode on a phone that can do it is just meh. And one can't deny the production level quality of video that's been coming from smartphones for sometime now. But then when I look at some of the still shots and clearly see what the AI is doing I sometimes don't like it. It almost feels fundamentally wrong at times.

Those AI shots may look really good but the edits sometimes just bug me because it's not what I would've done with standard photography. Like you said, you're subjecting that shot to someone else's opinion and vision, those who tuned the software. Conversely I have tried to take advantage of the AI once I get used to what a particular phone does and that's been fun and interesting.

Overall, phone cameras these days are amazing. I still well remember that jank old stuff from 10-15 years ago which was nearly useless in my opinion. Okay for rough documentation maybe but not much else in my opinion.

You know what could be interesting? What if Google for example implemented the whole jpeg+raw thing [they sort of do now] and extended it in photos where you could compare the AI version to the raw version as hints to edits? Somewhat like how you can currently compare original AI processed shots to your edits. Hmmm...

text:
Living in China - the photo effects are insane and I personally am in favour of things like merging different perspectives to make an unclear picture more clear but the Huawei side of things is really unsettling. It's all well and good when it's the moon but what about when face detection links into central servers? You can't turn it off if it's a feature you don't know about ... China has no qualms with this sort of thing.

Aside from that - what if it blurs content (faces/words/symbols) that are taboo? If the technology existed to preference one brand over another and phone manufacturers could profit from it I don't see any compelling reason they wouldn't do so.

text: Photos have never been the sameâ€¦ find an old person and ask to have a look at their old photo albums and slides. Kodak film was different to Fuji film, Kodachrome was different to Ektachrome and then there was Polaroidâ€¦ Fixed lenses were different to zoom lenses, camera flashes were different in size and directionâ€¦ just about the only thing that was the same was the size of the film - 35mmâ€¦ The majority of people just used cameras as a point and shoot. Today everyone gets to be a photographer and the level of control is simply unbelievable. Iâ€™m ok with photos looking different based on device and manufacturerâ€¦ all the photos from the tier one phones are excellent.

text:
here's my concern: the wealthy elite keep trying to usher in "the future" (or, it should be said, their vision of "the future") but, what are to do about the poor and famished in the meanwhile?

are we gonna "metaverse" them adequate/humane food, drink & shelter or somethin'?

we can't even figure basic crap out, for ensuring everyone gets to live a decent, hassle-free life; so, how are they going to establish their vision.. ..without pissing off the working class and the middle class even further than they \we\ already are? 

i've heard something about our power grid infrastructure's also needing a major upgrade: i heard from john oliver the price tag for that overhaul was.. ..what was it?  a trillion dollars?
yeah.
good luck with that.
of course.. ..there is the possibility we'll be having ourselves a nice little civil war in the meanwhile: a war we won't want but, since republican interests continue spiraling out of control (and out of sync from reality), it's a war we need



anyway.

smartphone cameras.

yeah, just allow me the option to switch that AI-altering crap off.
tks.



i also wonder, if this whole "thing" was by design: because, there was a time when there was no need to doubt the veracity of photos and videos you viewed
though, of course... ...if you're a loyal viewer of marques's channel, it's reasonable for me to conclude you already know all about the way which deep fakes has rent all that ability to trust asunder


there may just come a point in time when visual-media can no longer be admissible as evidence in court
"that wasn't me.  that's a deep fake.  can you prove otherwise?"


worryingly, i don't reckon there ever will be a way to categorically-distinguish fiction from reality.
at least, not for the working class and the middle class.

text: This is definitely true and something the mainstream wants, without realizing the potential consequences. For example, my family always wants to pose for photos, make sure that the lighting is good, smile and they always use the filters on the camera to change the color and make adjustments and then before posting on instagram they do even more filter applying and editing to look skinnier, etc. They always complain about me and my pictures because I prefer to take hundreds of candid photos of random moments when they're not paying attention or when they least expect it. And sure, a lot of those look blurry and have shit lighting, but within the hundred snapshots, when I manage to snag a picture of a genuine hug with a smile from getting a gift that no one was playing instagram influencer for.. THOSE are the pictures that have value to me. And there's no amount of editing that will replace them.

text:
Essentially when a camera takes an image the output is some combination of reality + biases + noise.

AI photography is essentially taking a range of inputs from the camera (and potentially other inputs within the code) and using a trained model to match reality (or in some cases something else such as a maximally good looking photo).

Using multiple photos can reduce noise. An alternative is if they already have the answer (for example image of the moon) they can rely on that input a lot more since that data has much less noise.

author: @knightbot1741

text:
First and foremost: You're a BEAUTIFUL PERSON! (You! Yes, you! The person reading this!) And I want you to be comfortable in your own skin.

I'm not okay with beauty filters and the idea of most of this virtualized removal or addition of things. I turn all these features off, and I would hate to see a future where there is no option to turn them off. I'm against the idea where every photo has to portray the perfect image. Life isn't perfect and we need to stop pretending it is and masquerading it on the internet. When did everyone become afraid to be who they are? Our imperfections make us unique, and that uniqueness is beautiful... and it saddens me that people really don't see this as the case anymore. There's nothing wrong with being you and showing who you are. Just be you! You're unique and beautiful just the way you are! I really feel like beauty filters are just a subtle form of digital body shaming. Not only do they skew your face in an image, but they also skew your own personal perception of yourself, and it's harmful to many people's self-worth and self-image. That said, filters can indeed be quite fun, and they do have their place in certain settings. However, I don't know exactly where that line in the sand should be drawn. There is a certain point where the photo you take no longer represents any form of reality, what happened, and what you experienced. If anything, I would like to see photo software and hardware get better at being able to represent real life colors, saturation, and light-levels, instead of the skewing of it. I would value those photos way more than the ones that have skewed it to make it look more "BEAUTIFIED". In fact, when I do rarely edit a photo, I am usually trying to bring that photo closer to the real thing. I edit the colors to be closer to what I actually see. This is way more valuable to me, because it is actually more representative of something that I experienced and was that I was compelled to take a photo of. I want to capture "THAT PARTICULAR" beauty that was compelling enough to take the photo of it in the first place. NOT do it an injustice by completing skewing it beyond what was experienced.

This is all of course just how I feel and is solely my opinion on the subject. I wholly understand and can accept other people's opinions on this subject of discussion.

However, where exactly is that line in the sand? I thought about it as I was writing this, and I think that the line in the sand is, "It has to be an option". An option that you have control over and can turn on or off at your own discretion and pleasure. Also, the user should be made aware that the feature even exists! In my current phone, it automatically had "beautify" features turned on. Now, I get how this could make people feel good about themselves in photos, and that's okay. But, when I took a photo of myself, I instantly thought the camera was crap. Because I knew that I don't look like that at all. The thing that was upsetting to me personally about it was that you're not even made aware that the filter is on. It was on by default. Furthermore, no explanation for what is going on is even offered in my phone about this. You have to determine what is going on yourself and dig through the settings to turn off these filters that are being applied to your photos. I guess what I mean in summation, is that not everyone is going to be like a smartphone power user and dig through every setting in every app in their phone. So, this default on "beauty" mode without telling your user that it is on and offering no explanation feels rather, as I said previously, disingenuous.

text:
This might pose a legal problem in courts as if you submit a video or image as evidence in support of your case and the opposing counsel can ask to have the evidence thrown out due to it being a modified or manipulated image. 

A recent case that was nationally televised, they spent nearly 2 days worth of testimony and side-bars discussing whether or not even digital zoom modified the original image enough to make the results not trustworthy.

For example, you accidently leave the makeup filter on and then take an image of an attacker. You go to court, submit your picture(s) and the attacker claims he never wears make-up, but the image clearly shows that he does. It leaves room for reasonable doubt of the authenticity of the image.

text:
I think this speaks to the classic misrepresentation of photos as honest or unbiased. If you accept that a photo, no matter how "unedited" it is, is always taken at a time with a perspective then automating all of these traditionally post processes is a no brainer. I also think we have already begun to have a healthier distrust of images and videos due to deep fakes. So in that context these photos seem both an obvious next step but also maybe less attractive. 
The other way to look at is that there are two types of photos. One to document and one to capture. If everyone is laughing and having a great time but the one photo you snapped was in a hectic moment and people's faces look like they're melting, is that more accurate or honest than the photo where the faces were swapped for sharp smiling ones? Which one capture the moment accurately? But then think of all the costume designers and makeup artists of the world trying to document thing for continuity. They may require a special "raw" app that doesn't clean up blemishes or take the shine off faces. So the perfect complexion in this instance is a worse document. 
So it's all fine. Just a new tool. Probably wedding photographers are the most at risk here. Their photos are most vulnerable to algorithmic thinking as well as the most expensive photos most people will buy in their life. (Not saying wedding phots are all the same, just that when people get offered bog standard photos taken by a friend with the latest phone against more interesting photos for $5000, some people are opting out of the 5K)

text:
My instinctive reaction is that it's ok for the phone to create a picture that I could have created given more time and maybe skills. For example, merging multiple shots of a group of people to get one where everyone looks their best. You can do this manually by taking many more photos, but it's more convenient if the phone does it. Same with HDR, or erasing a stray object from a shot. Conveniences are ok.

Automatically superimposing the moon is not OK. It's impossible to get that picture with that device. Impossible is not ok.

I'm not sure where I land on taking a selfie with the mona lisa where it looks like I'm the only one there. Technically, this is possible in real life. Maybe with an off-hours tour. On the other hand, there will more people with such selfies than is possible, so this is still grossly misrepresenting reality. So I guess even if it's possible that a person has such a photo, it's not OK if every person can have the same photo. This is similar to making a person look more beautiful. It's possible for a person to be nearly perfectly good looking, but if everyone looks like that in their photos, it just unrealistically raises expectations.

It really doesn't matter what we think though. I doubt there will be regulation about this, so companies will build it as soon as they can.

text:
I'm not okay with it.
I expect my cameras to capture the image my eyes are seeing. I expect them to capture what really happened, not an idealistic version.

Because in five years, if you looked at it, would you remember if that photo was real or modified?
 
If you always change your hairline, or tweak something in your face, and then forget about it later, would you be able to remember what you really looked like?
 
Photography brought us accurate portraits. That's what's so fascinating about looking at historical photos. It shows you exactly what happened in that moment in time. A picture of your grandparents, when they were young, that's accurate and will always be, as long as you have that photo. You'll always know what they looked like. Same for old pictures of cities, houses, sceneries, etc. They're a great portal into the past.
 
They wouldn't be portals into the past if the cameras erased people in the background, or applied beauty filters, etc
 
So no, I don't want that. Let it be a separate app for editing if you really want it. Not the camera. Camera should be accurate.

text: Ironically, the new tech mimics how the human brain works inasmuch as reality is created in our minds from sampled data from our eyes.  It's why human eyes are so easy to fool with magic tricks.  Our memories, likewise, are reconstructed data points that can have little resemblance to reality.  Memories are shockingly unreliable in courts of law.  I would imagine the next neat trick will be to eliminate lens distortion, so a scene is much as we see it with our eyes.

text: I'm slightly horrified. I work in corrections and we often have to go off video and stills when determining intent. Intent matters when someone is looking at sentencing. Could you imagine if you were displaying horror and disgust on your face but the image was replaced with a smiling gleeful face? The human element, ie. jury, psychologists, attorneys, etc. would turn you into a monster. Lets change the situation. Body language and facial expressions matter. I had to review photos of a non-consentual encounter. It was obvious from body language she was in a drugged state and her face still spoke volumes that she was not ok with what was happening. Over 90% of assaults are by someone you know. What if the images were altered by the camera and what the jury and court saw was her smiling aware face because the software substituted it in? No way should software be doing this without recording 2 images. The original and the edited. A marker should be used to identify an edited image.
author: @stitchedwicked7373

text:
I think, as long as it's little touchups, based on information gathered in like... a half second each way of taking a photo, I think it's fine. Because, as someone who has both known a lot of photographers and have done some myself, isn't that exactly what we do in Lightroom anyway? We apply a mask to get rid of a blemish, or blur the background, or add a filter to adjust your photo you shot in a LOG picture profile accidentally to look more natural, or... better?

Film photography was around for years and we never really questioned it. But, in 2021, if you look at a photo taken 30 years ago, it looks like a relic from a time long past. Colors are faded, lines are blurry, etc. Why? We were okay with those compromises, because we could pick up a cool little camera from Circuit City and be happy that we can capture any sort of moments.

Now it's gotten to the point where we are questioning things. Does X sensor emit more blue, or less blue? Does the Y sensor come out too sharp?

I just believe that some of these things are a result of us learning more about how cameras function (especially in the digital realm) and attempting to make it as accurate as possible. Some colors being more vibrant could be down to simply the sensor in the camera, or the added brightness might be a result of the sensor being too dim. So developers write code to correct that.

Little things like swapping the open eyes of a kid posing for a picture 100ms earlier for the closed eyes when they blinked the second you pressed the trigger... it's so close in time that it's unnoticeable. To me, that's technology making lives better, instead of ruining a memory with a crappy photo.

But when things get changed unnaturally, without giving the user an option to change it, and without even telling the user it's a thing... that's where I think the line is crossed. Apple's face smoothing algorithm on their new cameras might just be a result of a crappy sensor being upscaled... but it's likely software-driven. And, without the option to turn stuff like that off, I feel like that crosses the line. And don't even get me started about that Face AI thing you demoed. That's messed up.

text:
I honestly like this direction. Let's be real, the BEST photos in the world NEVER look like the real thing. Animal Photography, scenery, modeling, etc. All the photos you see from professional photographers are not only a capture of the instant it was taken, it is also the creative interpretation of the artist who took said picture. 

In studio photography, they have lightning, sets, super high end cameras to capture the picture of a human in the best possible light (pun intended). So good photography was never about portraying the reality of the moment.

With that being said, not everyone is a professional photographer/editor. So giving regular people the power to take "professional level" photography  is a good thing.

text:
I expected this video to be about how phone cameras warp peoples' bodies. I'm not talking about beauty features.. like because wide-angle cameras now are common in phones it seems that the photos taken with smartphones, especially Samsung ones warp peoples bodies in a way similar to how a fish-eye lens warps the pictures it takes.

I've seen pictures of everyone from thots on Instagram and just girls taking selfies to even like Tim Kennedy Mr. bad ass special forces guy be totally warped by the camera. At Christmas time my fiancee and her friend took pictures of themselves in these Christmas stripe stockings and it looks like their legs are 10 feet long and their bodies look super tiny.. And in the example of Tim Kennedy I've seen pictures of him where his head looks tiny and way too small for his body, and I've seen another friend of mine who does the classic hold the phone with both hands selfie and her arms look extremely long while her body and face are tiny.

But this was really super interesting and in some ways kind of the same thing a bit.. That whole thing where you can change every feature of your face is common in Asia.. I hate it. My fiancee takes pictures that don't even look like her. You can completely change your appearance and I think that's really not good for self-esteem when you feel like you don't look good unless you're changing the entirety of your face.

I've seen guys use it too it all has the same look. It makes guys look super weird almost like a pretty version of Golem from LOTR.

text: I'm a purist with most things, this includes photography. I want accuracy and authenticity, unless I'm going for something artsy, but even then I want to do the edits myself. I'm like this with music too. I don't generally like sampling, autotune, too many effects like reverb, or heavily edited pro-tool creations. I want it to sound like I'm in a room with the musicians playing right in front of me, raw. Everything is trending in a synthetic, manufactured, or deceptive direction nowadays and most younger people like myself embrace it or flat out don't care. Technology is making fake things seem so good that they're actually real (like even the faux wood in some new cars looks like real wood now, until you really start to examine it).

text:
Not an original take ofc, but I feel like this is for the most part in line with the history of photography and the natural progression of image â€œqualityâ€. Sensors are already quite good, so the innovation is in eliminating user error or enhancing the experience. TLDR; photos have never and will never be reality or even a true reflection of reality. There has always been someone or something making â€œdecisions.â€ I think a good question to ask is are those decisions intelligible to the user, and do they closely enough evoke the intent of the user. 

For someone at Disneyland the answer is prolly â€œdid I get the shot of my family or do I have to sit here and fiddle with my camera for another few minutes.â€ For a photojournalist, maybe they require an image that is transparent about â€œdecisionsâ€ it made and does it reflect closely enough to reality to be of journalistic quality. This may be part of why we see even separate apps for different use cases on the same phone! The use cases fork so heavily because the answers to those questions change over time.

text: Here's a question down that same train of logic. If we (humans) take enough pictures of the earth and they become logged in a central data base; how much storage space could AI save by imposing pictures on pictures instead of saving images over again? If you have enough selfies making different faces, instead of saving a face that is almost identical to a previous image it could just reference an already saved image. Faces may be a bit complex, but there are lot of places visited in the world that probably have almost exact images taking up space on many different phones or cloud storage spaces. If somebody else had a 4k picture and you only took a 1080P picture of the same thing could it upscale your image to be better than the picture you took?

text: My wife and I are Asians. Ever since the iPhone 12, both our iPhones regularly pick photos (1/10, < 1/10 before) where her eyes are closed. I can't get it to stop overcompensating. I can only suspect something is going on. Just like how we expect informed consent to tracking/ use of personal information today, I think we should expect algorithms used to be explained in simple terms and require consent. Then, like data breaches, fines when algorithms are imposed without consent, and mandatory disclosures and fines when algorithms fail.

text:
I think this makes sense in a social media driven society. Most people want their Instagram feed to be their highlight reel (even if it's not based 100% in reality) and any tool that adds to that is something that those users would find helpful. 

On the other hand, I don't see this technology (or at least not to this extreme) come to professional cameras. Big features of "professional" cameras like 14-bit Raw files or 11 stops of dynamic range don't necessarily make your photos look better, they just give you more control over the end result. 

It's kind of interesting to think about even when 'pro' camera features come to a smartphone, they are more about producing easy and pleasing results than they are about professional levels of control. I remember LG adding a log profile to one of their phones and nobody used it lol.
author: @JoshuaWayt

text: So has anyone thought about the legal implications of this? For example, what will be permissible as evidence in a courtroom?
author: @ICDeadPeeps

text:
I've been wondering about the legal implications of this. Is it possible that computational photography gets to a point where it's inadmissible evidence in court, because they are a program's interpretation of reality? What if you took the Pixel 6 feature mentioned around 6:00 in this video, and added facial recognition? So the software notices a blurry face, but it detects who it is from your Google Photos account and super-imposes their clear face onto the photo? That's probably possible with today's technology.

But what if that photos was submitted as evidence in a court case? Is it really a photo of a person at a crime scene? Or is it Google's software's best guess of who was in the photo, and enhanced using software?

text: See we are defined by the laws of physics meaning that there is only so much light that a smart phone camera can capture. Thus it is inevitable that we will reach a point where smarphone camera hardware (sensors and lenes) stagnate in progress. Yet we are not bound by the same laws of nature when it comes to software, meaning that with enough research and design almost anything is possible when it comes to AI image enhancement. Smartphone companies are then put into a box where they are forced to alter images further and further from reality to become marketable. This scares me because one day images might be mererly AI generated 3d models or paintings that disaplay little to none of the origional light gathered by the sensor.
author: @evanbrorby

text:
I think we're already past this point. Yes, pro photographers want the unprocessed RAW, but then they beat the hell out of it with editing and alterations. As they say, it's an artistic view of what they captured... I think at the end this only harms the industry itself. People get used to these over the top images and they loose trust to what was genuinely captured vs edited. Loosing trust, means you will assume by default pictures have been manipulated. Is that good or bad? Not sure, but personally I believe this does a disservice to photographers that go the extra mile to capture real-life moments, at the right time. That's the actual art, that takes skill to accomplish.

I will start having a serious problem when altering computational photography starts creeping into the RAW files of actual cameras... For smartphones, call me crazy (or old), I would honestly prefer them not to have cameras at all. They're just ugly monstrosities, that have become the norm for some reason. I would choose cheaper and longer battery lasting phones every single time. Just give me the "without cameras" iPhone with true edge-to-edge screen!

text:
4:00 Not entirely right. The moon's eccentric (slightly elliptical) orbit causes it to appear differently all the time. It changes apparent size by roughly 10% over the course of its orbit. The angle of its visible face also changes slightly (if you take an identical shot every night over one lunation and animate it, it looks like the moon is rocking very slightly back and forth). On top of that, the Earth is large enough and the moon close enough that you see the moon from a different angle depending on what part of the planet you're on.

While it's certainly possible to map the surface of the moon to a 3D model that could then account for your location and the moon's apparent size, angle, and phase, I doubt anyone at the phone companies would consider it a priority worth spending any time on. Especially since the moon is extremely easy to take a picture of -- if the system is programmed to recognize the moon, it can easily drop to a slower ISO and faster shutter speed and give you a good picture.

I like what you're bringing up in this video, but at the same time I think you have enough photography/videography experience to know better than to suggest that there's ever such a thing as 100% honesty in photography.

The same exact photo can be taken with different settings and yield very different results even without any post-processing applied. Which one is the "real" one? I think it was Camber Motion that posted a video a few years ago about how dramatically an image is affected just by changing the focal length of the lens. Photographers make a lot of decisions in how to take a picture (many of those decisions become second nature based on experience and preference, so they happen very quickly and on the fly, but everything from which lens to use, what ISO, f-stop, etc., etc.).

My favorite aspect of photography is that very lie. It's all about making the viewer see what the photographer intends. And it can be just as well accomplished with a smart phone's processing, once you (as the photographer) get familiar with that phone's pictures and understand how to work it to give the results you want.

As for the typical non-photographer's use of a camera, I think they just want a "good" picture without worrying about settings. A picture where one person in the crowd is blinking or halfway into a sneeze is considered bad and unwanted, instead of just being an honest memory. If they recognize it at the time, they'll likely take the picture again and delete the "bad" one.

If it is defined by the micro-seconds the shutter is open then it is OK if a person blinked or whatever. but if that moment in time is defined by the 10 seconds you are taking to frame your shot, then it is not entirely dishonest if AI were to scan through the 10 seconds to identify the perfect face of everyone.. author: @ArthurMuteesasira

text:
Â @ArthurMuteesasiraÂ  I think "that moment in time" to most people means the ideal image that's already in their mind's eye of everyone smiling and looking their best. Most people consider a truly candid image as a "bad" picture, because something wasn't "correct" about someone(s) in the shot. Those are the people that will be using features like these. Those are the people who are using the new Pixel 6 feature that can erase things/people in a picture. They never wanted an "honest" picture, but an ideal image that lines up with how they'd rather remember it.

A relative minority of people will instead prefer the "flawed" picture, or will want to be in full control instead of handing it over to the AI, and will disable those features.

For myself, I often don't use my phone's camera's enhancements. But sometimes I do.

text: This video is a primer in my worry about evidence presented in trials. Photos have generally been acceptable as evidence so long as they can be determined to be unaltered or fair representations. Smartphone companies having some interest in hiding the 'enhancements' that get done on camera photos seems to me like something that will cause a bit of chaos in courtrooms. Maybe smartphone photos start getting refused as evidence and trials miss out on key evidence. Maybe nothing is done and trials get swamped with photos that are not fair representations but also are not rejected due to being thought to be unaltered photos.

text: You push the button, you get a single frame. One bare moment, an image to represent a memory. You hold the button, you get a longer period of time. What's wrong with letting software preserve the best it can from a longer period of time, to make a better memory? Compare that idea of an ideal group selfie, to the old photos everybody's parents have where someone looks drunk or weird because their eyes are closed, or something... We've decided we want to save better memories, and our technology is helping us do that. Of course it should be optional, but think... How happy are your parents that when they finally got people together for a moment IRL to take a picture... It came out "Perfect" the "First Time"? That's what these things are for.

text:
smartphones are limited in space, which is why they use computation to enhance the photos so much. i just wonder what would happen, if the camera companies combined their superior hardware with the "computational photography" of smartphones. yes yes they do this to some extent, but their focus is at making the hardware as best as possible. there is no "best of the both worlds" that i've yet seen. smartphone companies are the best at the computational aspect, because they have to. they cannot put full frame sensors in their phones. and camera companies aren't that interested in investing into the computational part because their customers don't exactly care about that, they want control, they want raw photos for them to edit. 

i just wish they made some joint venture into this so find out just how much can be done. so far i feel like we have to choose between one and the other, and no best of both worlds exist.

text:
I kinda have mixed feelings. But for general purpose use and the broadest consumer base - it's not as bad as it might sound.
Most people think of photographs as capturing reality and truth. And from a journalistic and historic point of view it's accurate and there are the dangers where "tampering" with reality is a bad thing.
But in an everyday casual use case - photos are often mostly about capturing memories rather than super-accurate reality.
And if people have additional tools to their disposal and aren't "pros" - but are able to capture an awesome photo of that moment and create a great memory of that - it will always be a better option than capturing a shaky, blurry, bad-lighting, closed-eyes situation picture that is true and accurate - but no one wants to rewatch it later ever again.
But the important thing is that the obvious AI stuff should always be optional - never mandatory. I want a phone where I can choose if I need that kind of assistance. Because sometimes you might want that "bad picture" on purpose.
But other than that. I like the smart phones a lot.
I take most my pictures nowadays with my phone - whilst my to professional Full Frame DSLRs don't get much use anymore. 
Even on holidays I LOVE being able to create photos AND video of great quality without having to lug around kilos/pounds of camera gear. ðŸ¤·ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ It's insane how much the hardware evolved over just 20-30 years.
Just two decades ago people had to pay expensive helicopters to shoot aerial footage.
Nowadays almost every youtube travel video has crazy aerial footage in crispest hollywood quality. ðŸ¤¯ðŸ¤¯ðŸ¤¯

author: @HeyTylerAustin

text:
I'm highly against it.  It waters down what the real image should be, and is not good for our brain's memory.   Our brain processes and recalls memory based on facial expressions, allowing us to "re-feel" and relive the moment years later.  Peoples' memories will be obscured because Grandma will see little Johnny always smiling in pictures, but in reality little Johnny was a brat that wouldn't sit still for the camera. That's the memory she should have, that little Johnny didn't like getting his picture taken. But instead, all of her grandchildren will have a perfect smile.  Perfection is not good, it's fake. 

Also, this presents additional challenges for law enforcement and our court systems.  It may get to a point to where photographs are no longer considered as evidence, because they'll be deemed as likely being altered.  I see this as going down a slipper slope, with a lot of potential for deception.
author: @RADERFPV

text: I feel like this is exactly one of those things were most people will say: "Cool! But let me turn it off." That example at the end of the video is an amazing one, as someone who takes most of his interesting pictures in somewhat tourist-y areas, I always hate realising that there are still a few people in the shot after I've already left, or don't get to take the shot I want because I'm in a hurry and don't have the time to wait for people to leave. In those cases, of course it would be amazing to just get a 'perfect' picture with my phone within seconds. But even though it'll be a pretty photo, and it provides a somewhat romanticized memory of that moment, it isn't what really happened. As long as there's still a toggle for all these features, preferably big and on the main screen instead of buried in a settings menu somewhere, it's a cool evolution. Even though it's somewhat scary to think what else it could be used for.

text: Iâ€™d actually like a large country to legislate that phone cameras must include a mode (maybe even a separate downloadable app made by the hardware manufacturer if they want to supply it that way)  that removes all of the smart corrections and just gives me an actual image that is as unprocessed as possible. Maybe allowing distortion-correction for wide angle images would be okay. But thatâ€™s it. Give me a standard auto-white balance with the ability to change it, autofocus, auto-ISO, and auto exposure time, and maybe the ability to adjust those last three.  Why? Because letâ€™s say I need to send my doctor a photo of my skin condition... what if I canâ€™t turn Appleâ€™s skin-smoothing algorithm off (you canâ€™t). Do I have to go out and buy a $400 camera that is JUST a camera? I usually donâ€™t like the â€œtell congress to regulate itâ€ approach, but in this case I think itâ€™s necessary. We use cell phone photos and videos to document things, and those become court evidence in murder trials. They are medical information for my doctor. They document the condition of your apartment when you move in so you can get your damn deposit back. If the skin-smoothing / noise-filtering algorithm starts erasing the blemishes from the wall, it could cost your deposit when you move out. I want this shit LEGISLATED. I donâ€™t care about requiring USB-C on the iPhone. I want to be able to use the camera to capture actual images of whatâ€™s actually there. Iâ€™m dropping somewhere near a thousand dollars on a phone. Iâ€™d like some consumer protections so I can use it in a most obvious fashion.

text:
This is just one branch of a larger conversation we all should be having. 

Should we ever allow AI to kill people in war?
What will the ultimate answer of the Trolley problem be for all autonomous cars?
How much should we be able to change our looks on cameras?

It's a whole movie trope to say "we can, but should we?" And we are about to hit a moment where that's required, and I'm sure I'm not alone in seeing the dangers of a corporation answering all these major questions without discussion.

The quicker we have this conversation, the better. Personally, I know I don't have the qualifications in either philosophy, AI development, or ethics to even begin to think about this appropriately and I would be more than happy to read a number of papers from a number of brilliant minds in their fields to either agree or disagree with via some sort of vote.
Others may have serious moral obligations to speak up, and there needs to be a space for that.

The one thing I know for sure is that we have no viable structure to be able to even have this conversation on a national or international scale. A single term President should NOT have the ability to define technology for generations to come, nor should two parties defined as an alternative to the other. We need serious systemic changes to even begin; a brand new apparatus and infrastructure to discuss these major upcoming questions not just in AI, but a variety of other upcoming technological revolutions.

Without it, we're fucked.

text:
Well said! I remember from my documentaryfilmhistory-course at university that documentaries can be seen as a "creative treatment of actuality", which means that a documentary isn't necessarily the true picture. Up to now we have seen pictures as something hard, something untouchable. They can be used in court to prove someone guilty of a crime. 
The truth is to many subjective and it depends on who is telling the story. We consider documentaries on TV documentaries because someone (often the filmmaker) decided they are. Everyone just accepts that. I am therefore  wondering at what scale these types of AI-edited pictures will be seen as the truth even though we now say they aren't. Aren't they true because they just merge two real photos? What's the difference between doing this and using the portrait-mode which only blurs the background with AI considering most phones are not able to do it with hardware?

My argument:
You should edit your photos. The photo is what the camera saw, not what YOU experienced at the moment. Editing photos is one way to show other people what you actually saw and took in.

But are they really? Or is it just our association with them?
For journalistic and historic purposes I'm with you.
But besides that.... before photography was invented - artists made paintings of people.
But these where expensive and only rich people could afford that. And all those historic paintings NEVER depict true, accurate reality.

Then photography came along and democratized capturing memories for the common man.
Photos are much more about freezing a particular memory rather than portraying truth in that sense.
Otherwise we wouldn't tamper with photos in lightroom and photoshop. No one tries to recreate the boring, normal colors we see.
Mostly people try to "enhance" their picture in some ways. Just a small change of contrast is already a manipulation of "reality" in that sense. And has even been done before computers in the dark room with analog film. A lot of manipulation is done within the film development process and the end product is always the "vision" of the photographer - not the true reality as it was in that moment. ðŸ¤”

text: Begs the question though. Can we ever? Look at film, the first method of truly capturing light at a point in time in a format that can be viewed later. There is differences between film stocks, camera lens, grain, sharpness; these all result in different versions of the same reality. Perhaps its philosophical.

text:
Â @josuastangl7140Â  Yeah, but what's your reference point then?
Do you go back to the scene with your computer and calibrate the picture you're developing with reality? ðŸ¤·ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ Other than referencing white-balance every other adjustment is just your interpretation of what you think you saw.... or most likely what your brain remembers and thinks looks good. Because most people don't even work on 100% calibrated screens - so the colors you see might not be accurate and then you're basing your judgement off of that. ðŸ¤·ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ðŸ¤” 
If you take 10 people developing the same picture - you'll receive 10 different results - because our brain and eyes aren't as accurate as we like to think. And even though the differences might be small - which version is the truest? And who decides that? You see. It's a complicated matter already.
